title: A Randomized, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled Trial to Assess the Efficacy and Safety of AXS-05 for the Treatment of Agitation in Subjects With Dementia of the Alzheimer's Type
description_brief: This is a multi-center, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study, to assess the efficacy and safety of AXS-05 in the treatment of agitation in patients with Alzheimer's disease.

categories.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in CMAI Total Score
outcomeMeasures.description: The Cohen-Mansfield Agitation Inventory (CMAI) is a 29-item caregiver-rated questionnaire that assesses the frequency of agitation-related and disruptive behaviors in subjects with dementia. The scale contains 29 behaviors or items organized into four subscales: physically aggressive, physically non-aggressive, verbally aggressive, and verbally non-aggressive. The CMAI is administered by interviewing the caregiver and asking him or her to rate the frequency with which the subject manifests each behavior using a seven-point scale: 1=never (better outcome), 7=several times an hour (worse outcome). The CMAI total score is the sum of the scores for all of the items in the CMAI. CMAI total scores range from a minimum of 29 (better outcome) to a maximum of 203 (worse outcome).

seriousEvents.organSystem: Neoplasms benign, malignant and unspecified (incl cysts and polyps)
Neoplasms benign, malignant and unspecified (incl cysts and polyps)

explanation_target: Reason: The investigational product is AXS‑05, an oral combination of dextromethorphan and bupropion described as an NMDA receptor antagonist and sigma‑1 receptor agonist (a small‑molecule/combination drug), not a biologic. citeturn0search0turn0search1

Act: The trial’s stated purpose is to assess efficacy and safety of AXS‑05 for the treatment of agitation in patients with Alzheimer’s disease (a behavioral/neuropsychiatric symptom), and it is a randomized, double‑blind, placebo‑controlled study. This indicates the intervention is being tested to manage neuropsychiatric symptoms rather than to modify underlying AD pathology. citeturn0search4turn0search1

Act (drug evidence): Published summaries and press releases explicitly identify AXS‑05 as dextromethorphan‑bupropion and report positive phase 3 results for Alzheimer’s‑related agitation (ACCORD/other trials), confirming the drug identity and clinical context. citeturn0search0turn0search3turn0news12

Reflect: Although AXS‑05 is a small‑molecule combination (not a biologic), the trial’s objective is to treat agitation (a neuropsychiatric/behavioral symptom). Per the category definitions, the correct classification is 'neuropsychiatric symptom improvement' rather than a disease‑targeted category. No information in the provided description indicates an amyloid/tau‑targeting disease‑modifying intent. citeturn0search3turn0search0
explanation_agent: Reason: The investigational product is AXS‑05 (dextromethorphan‑bupropion), a small‑molecule combination with multiple pharmacologic actions — notably uncompetitive NMDA receptor antagonism and sigma‑1 receptor agonism, plus effects on monoamine transporters and nicotinic receptors — and the trial purpose is symptomatic treatment of agitation in Alzheimer's disease rather than targeting core amyloid/tau pathology. citeturn0search4turn0search2

Act: Extracted evidence — AXS‑05 is described by the developer and peer‑reviewed literature as a multimodal agent (dextromethorphan component: NMDA antagonist, sigma‑1 agonist, nicotinic antagonist, SERT/NET inhibition; bupropion: increases dextromethorphan bioavailability and is a NDRI) and has been tested in Phase‑3 trials for Alzheimer’s‑related agitation (ACCORD/ADVANCE programs). The ACCORD Phase‑3 randomized discontinuation trial showed relapse‑prevention benefit; multiple company/press reports summarize the Phase‑3 program and regulatory plans. citeturn0search2turn0search4turn0search0turn0search3

Reflect: CADRO classification: because the drug acts on several neurotransmitter receptors and transporters (and has multimodal CNS activity) and the trial is aimed at improving a neuropsychiatric symptom rather than disease modification, the most appropriate CADRO label is R) Multi‑target. An alternative, narrower classification could be D) Neurotransmitter Receptors (given NMDA/sigma‑1 actions), but the documented multiple mechanisms support 'Multi‑target' per the instruction to use R when multiple targets are indicated. Confirmed by published descriptions and trial reports. citeturn0search1turn0news12
